user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.2 is: A project shall not contain dead code.
Any operation that is executed but whose removal would not affect program behaviour constitutes dead code. Notes:
1. The behaviour of an embedded sytem is often determined not just by the nature of its actions, but also by the time at which they occur.
2. unreachable code is not dead code, as it cannot be executed.
3.Initialization is not the same as an assignment operation and is therfore not a candidate for dead code.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_ip_addr_to_key:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
MHD_ip_addr_to_key (const struct sockaddr_storage *addr,
                    socklen_t addrlen,
                    struct MHD_IPCount *key)
{
  memset (key,
          0,
          sizeof(*key));

  /* IPv4 addresses */
  if (sizeof (struct sockaddr_in) <= (size_t) addrlen)
  {
    if (AF_INET == addr->ss_family)
    {
      key->family = AF_INET;
      memcpy (&key->addr.ipv4,
              &((const struct sockaddr_in *) addr)->sin_addr,
              sizeof(((const struct sockaddr_in *) NULL)->sin_addr));
      return MHD_YES;
    }
  }

#ifdef HAVE_INET6
  if (sizeof (struct sockaddr_in6) <= (size_t) addrlen)
  {
    /* IPv6 addresses */
    if (AF_INET6 == addr->ss_family)
    {
      key->family = AF_INET6;
      memcpy (&key->addr.ipv6,
              &((const struct sockaddr_in6 *) addr)->sin6_addr,
              sizeof(((const struct sockaddr_in6 *) NULL)->sin6_addr));
      return MHD_YES;
    }
  }
#endif

  /* Some other address */
  return MHD_NO;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I have limited the suspicious fragments to the explicit initialization at the top (memset) and the two address-handling branches (the IPv4 block and the IPv6 block guarded by #ifdef). Other parts of the function were not included because they are not candidates for dead-code investigation in this context: the function signature and return type are the required interface; the final return (the 'Some other address' comment and the return MHD_NO;) is needed to indicate failure when neither address branch applies and its removal would change observable behaviour; the preprocessor guard (#ifdef HAVE_INET6) is a compile-time inclusion mechanism (not runtime dead code) and so is not itself a runtime dead-code candidate; basic control-structure tokens (braces, comments) and the literal return tokens are structural and not dead code. No other statements outside the three listed fragments appear to be operations that are executed yet removable without affecting program behaviour, so they do not require further investigation for MISRA C Rule 2.2 compliance.
